choices.A: Any available IP address in the WAN (port1) subnet 10.200.1.0/24

discussion.content: The answer is C

comments.content: no its b..i have tested in lab

discussion.content: C is correct, VIP doesnt affect SNAT

Correct answer is B 10.200.1.10

As port forwarding is disable it will take VIP external IP address if port forwarding is enable then it will take WAN interface IP address, in this case it will be 10.200.1.1. I have tested in my LAB.
Answer is B, Destination NAT static takes precedence of nat enabled on this policy.

Guys, you are missing the point that this is a stateful Firewall. It matters in which direction the connection is established. In this case from LAN(port2) to WAN(port1).

So the Firewall Policy ID 1 matches and has NAT Enabled. in this view we are unable to look at the adress configured for NAT. It could be the interface adress shown above in the network topology, 10.200.1.1 or it could be the IP from the virtual IP Setup. 

In this virtual IP Setup the IP 10.200.1.10 is assigned for being used for Destination NAT from WAN (port1) to LAN (port2). 10.200.1.10 is in the same subnet like the interface adress 10.200.1.1.

So the source could be 10.200.1.1, which will be the first adress allocated. it could also be any other allocated IP adress in that subnet. We already know one additional adress.

So Answer A is the correct one.

I agree with ccsa_ccse!
The correct answer is B in this case.
The correct answer for this is B because the port forwarding is disabled so the reciprocity still exists.
The answer to this one is B because Port Forwarding is disabled. If Port Forwarding was enabled, it would be C.

correct is B because the port forwarding is desable
if the port forwarding is enable then the answer will be C
answer is C
C because extreme mode is activated

Correct answer C

av-failopen pass (default): All new sessions pass without inspection

but the 3 memory thresholds : red, extreme and green are set with the values:

green: 82%
red: 88%
extreme: 95%

these values serve as a reference for the “memory used” which in this case is 97% used. So…

Fortigate Infrastructure 6.2 Study Guide page 396 says:
However, if the “memory usage exceeds” the “extreme threshold”, new sessions “are always dropped”, regardless of the FortiGate configuration.
C is correct because of the extreme mode activated.

Answer is A. fail-open mode is pass. the default mode when allowing trafic is more important than security. the other mode are off and one-shot. 
https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortigate/6.0.0/handbook/681934/conserve-mode
The answer is A, FortiGate Infraestructure 6.2 Study Guide pag. 396

comments.content: my fault, i didnt see the 95% in the RAM, the correct answer is C

choices.D: It is allowed and inspected, as long as the inspection is flow based.
choices.B: It is allowed and inspected, as long as the only inspection required is antivirus.
choices.A: It is allowed, but with no inspection.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

The exhibit shows FortiGate configuration and the output of the debug command.
Based on the diagnostic output, how is the FortiGate handling the traffic for new sessions that require proxy based inspection?
Which statement about SSL VPN settings for an SSL VPN portal is true?

choices.C: By default, the SSL VPN portal requires the installation of a client's certificate.
choices.B: By default, the admin GUI and the SSL VPN portal use the same HTTPS port.
choices.D: By default, FortiGate uses WINS servers to resolve names.
choices.A: By default, DNS split tunneling is enabled.

discussion.content: B is correct - FGT_Security-6.2, p.591 - 592
B. First criteria it would be admin distance which is equal. Next it will be the lowest priority value which is port 1. Two routes goes to the routing table but the port1 is used until goes down.
B is correct

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

The exhibit shows two static routes.
Which option accurately describes how FortiGate will handle these two routes to the same destination?

choices.B: FortiGate will use the port1 route as the primary candidate.
choices.D: FortiGate will route twice as much traffic to the port2 route.
choices.C: FortiGate will load balance all traffic across both routes.
choices.A: FortiGate will only activate the port1 route in the routing table.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

//IMG//

The exhibit shows the IPS sensor configuration and forward traffic logs.
An administrator has configured the WINDOWS_SERVERS IPS sensor in an attempt to determine whether the influx of HTTPS traffic is an attack attempt, or not.
After applying the IPS sensor, FortiGate is still not generating any IPS logs for the HTTPS traffic.
What is a possible reason for this?

discussion.content: Security manual page 555 suggests that deep packet inspection is required to reliably detect attacks in encrypted traffic. Answer C makes sense once dealing with SSL traffic, FortiGate expects you to enable full SSL inspection.

comments.content: Agreed. As you apply filters to "servers" and "windows", a lot of signatures are put in place to block it. As said in the statement, no logs were generated, so no full SSL inspection is enable.

discussion.content: The Security Manual talk a lot about signatures, so that the reason I belive is answer A
what page is this in the security manual? Why not A?
C is correct
B is correct

choices.B: The IPS filter is missing the Protocol:HTTPS option.
choices.A: The HTTPS signatures have not been added to the sensor.
choices.C: The firewall policy is not using a full SSL inspection profile.
choices.D: A DoS policy should be used, instead of an IPS sensor.
